email.description: The email address of the user.

createdAt.description: The date and time the user account was created.

DecisionScenario.title: DecisionScenario
DecisionScenario.description: Represents a decision scenario created by a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the decision scenario.

userId.description: Reference to the User who created this scenario. (Relationship: User 1:N DecisionScenario)

subject.description: The subject of the decision scenario.

description.description: A detailed description of the decision scenario.

createdAt.description: The date and time the decision scenario was created.

DecisionOption.title: DecisionOption
DecisionOption.description: Represents a single option within a decision scenario.

id.description: Unique identifier for the decision option.

decisionScenarioId.description: Reference to the DecisionScenario this option belongs to. (Relationship: DecisionScenario 1:N DecisionOption)

name.description: The name of the decision option.

description.description: A detailed description of the decision option.

aiWeight.description: The AI weighting for this option.

Comment.title: Comment
Comment.description: Represents a comment on a decision scenario.

userId.description: Reference to the User who created this comment. (Relationship: User 1:N Comment)

decisionScenarioId.description: Reference to the DecisionScenario this comment belongs to. (Relationship: DecisionScenario 1:N Comment)

text.description: The text content of the comment.

createdAt.description: The date and time the comment was created.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to support the Advisify AI application's features, focusing on decision scenarios, options, and community interaction. It prioritizes authorization independence and clear security rules.

*   **Users:** User data is stored in `/users/{userId}`. This path-based ownership ensures that only the user can access their own data.
*   **Decision Scenarios:** Decision scenarios are stored within each user's document at `/users/{userId}/decisionScenarios/{decisionScenarioId}`. This leverages path-based ownership, providing straightforward security rules (a user can only read/write their own scenarios).
*   **Decision Options:** Options for each scenario are nested under `/users/{userId}/decisionScenarios/{decisionScenarioId}/options/{optionId}`. This continues the path-based ownership model.
*   **Public Scenarios:** Public scenarios, for community sharing, are stored in `/publicScenarios/{scenarioId}`. To ensure secure `list` operations (QAPs), we denormalize the `userId` of the scenario creator into each document. Comments are stored in a subcollection `/publicScenarios/{scenarioId}/comments/{commentId}`. To achieve Authorization Independence, each comment document will include the `userId` of the user who created the comment.

This structure ensures authorization independence by avoiding `get()` calls in security rules. Path-based ownership for user-specific data and denormalization of authorization data (userId in public scenarios and comments) are key to atomic operations and simplified security rules. Segregation of user-owned vs. public data improves security posture. The structure enables secure `list` operations (QAPs) because access control is based on the presence of user IDs, either via path ownership or denormalized fields, rather than filtering based on document content.
